title: How to Cook Chana Dal

steps.headline: Rinse the chana dal and put it in a pot with cold water.
steps.description: Put 1 cup (240 g) of chana dal into a fine mesh strainer and run water over it until the water runs clear. Put the chana dal into a pot and pour in 3 ⁄2 cups (830 ml) of water. Use a pot that's at least 3-quarts (2.8 liters) in size.

steps.headline: Simmer the covered chana dal for 35 to 40 minutes over medium heat.
steps.description: Turn the burner to high so the water begins to boil. Then turn the burner down to medium or medium-low so the water bubbles gently. Put the lid on the pot and simmer the chana dal until it's tender. Stir the chana dal frequently to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the pan. If the chana dal absorbs all of the water before it softens, stir in a few tablespoons of water at a time.

steps.headline: Whisk and cool the chana dal while you temper the oil.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and remove the lid from the pot. Whisk the chana dal so it breaks down and becomes smooth. Set the chana dal aside while you temper spices in the oil. The chana dal will continue to thicken as it cools.

steps.headline: Fry 1 tablespoon (6 g) of cumin seeds in oil over medium heat.
steps.description: Pour 3 tablespoons (44 ml) of vegetable oil into a small pot and turn the burner to medium heat. Once the oil shimmers, stir in the cumin seeds and cook them for 20 to 30 seconds. The cumin will smell fragrant once it's finished frying.

steps.headline: Stir in and sauté the onion, chilies, and ginger for 4 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Chop 1 small onion and prick 3 to 4 whole green chilies a few times with a fork. Add these to the hot oil in the pot along with a 3/4-in (1.9 cm) piece of fresh ginger root that you've peeled and cut into thin strips. The onions should soften and begin to turn brown.

steps.headline: Puree the garlic and tomatoes.
steps.description: Peel 3 whole garlic cloves and put them into a food processor. Cut 3 tomatoes into large pieces and add them in. Cover and pulse the tomatoes and garlic until they're completely smooth. If you don't have a food processor, you can use a blender.

steps.headline: Stir the puree into the oil along with the spices and water.
steps.description: Scoop the pureed tomato mixture into the oil and stir in ¾ teaspoons (2 g) of ground turmeric, ¾ teaspoons (2 g) of garam masala, 1½ teaspoons (4 g) of ground coriander, and 7 tablespoons (100 ml) of water. You can also add salt and pepper according to your taste.

steps.headline: Simmer the sauce for 15 to 20 minutes over medium heat.
steps.description: Let the sauce bubble gently and cook it until the oil floats to the top. You may have to turn the burner down to medium-low if the mixture spits or bubbles too much.

steps.headline: Stir the chana dal into the sauce and bring it to a boil.
steps.description: If the chana dal still looks dry, add a few spoonfuls of water to loosen it. Turn the burner to medium-high so the chana dal comes to a boil.

steps.headline: Mix in the chopped cilantro and serve the chana dal.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and stir in a handful of chopped cilantro. Then serve the chana dal immediately. Consider serving it with rice, chapatis, or flatbread. Refrigerate leftover chana dal in an airtight container for up to 3 to 5 days.

steps.headline: Put the dal, tomato, salt, turmeric, chili, and masala in a pressure cooker.
steps.description: Measure 3/4 cup (158 g) of chana dal into a pressure cooker. Stir in 1 chopped tomato, 3/4 teaspoon (4 g) of salt, 1/4 teaspoon (0.75 g) of turmeric powder, 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of red chili or cayenne pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of garam masala. Use a pressure cooker that's at least 6-quarts (5.6 liters) in size.

steps.headline: Pour in water and close the pressure cooker.
steps.description: Stir in 1 1/2 to 2 cups (355 to 473 ml) of water. Add less of the water if you like thicker chana dal. Then lower the lid and set the valve so it seals.

steps.headline: Pressure cook the chana dal for 12 minutes on high pressure.
steps.description: Push the manual button so you can select high pressure. Adjust the timer to 12 minutes. The chana dal should absorb most of the water and become soft once it's pressure cooked. You don't have to soak the chana dal before cooking it.

steps.headline: Release the pressure and stir the chana dal.
steps.description: Use the natural pressure release so the pressure gradually reduces, then open the pressure cooker. Stir the chana dal to help it break down. Close the lid and press the keep warm/cancel button to clear the setting. Then push the sauté button to keep the chana dal on low heat while you temper the oil.

steps.headline: Fry the cumin and mustard seeds for 30 seconds.
steps.description: Pour 2 teaspoons (9.9 ml) of vegetable, coconut, or canola oil into a small skillet or pan and turn the burner to medium heat. Once the oil shimmers, stir in 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of cumin seeds and 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of mustard seeds. The seeds will crackle and become fragrant as they fry.

steps.headline: Stir in and fry the hing, garlic, and red chilies.
steps.description: Mince 2 cloves of garlic and stir them into the hot oil along with 1 pinch of hing (asafoetida) and 2 dried red chilies. Fry the spices for another 30 seconds or until the garlic browns a little.

steps.headline: Stir the spiced oil into the cooked chana dal.
steps.description: Turn off the burner and pour the spiced oil into the pressure cooker. Stir the mixture so the oil is combined with the cooked chana dal. If you prefer smoother chana dal, mash a little of the mixture with the back of a spoon.

steps.headline: Add lemon juice and cilantro before you serve the chana dal.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of lemon juice into the chana dal and taste it. Add the other 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of juice if you want a sharper flavor. Sprinkle the chana dal with 1 tablespoon (1 g) of chopped cilantro and serve it immediately with boiled potatoes, flatbread, or rice. Store the leftover chana dal in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 to 5 days.
